So, I'm going to talk today about uh
collecting stories um in uh some
unconventional ways. This is a picture
of me from a very awkward stage in my
life. Um, you might enjoy the awkwardly
tight cut off pajama bottoms with
balloons. Anyway, was a time when I was
mainly interested in collecting
imaginary stories. So, this is a picture
of me holding one of the first
watercolor paintings I ever made. And
recently, I've been much more interested
in collecting stories from reality, so
real stories. And, uh, specifically, I'm
interested in collecting my own stories,
uh, stories from the internet, and then
recently stories from life, which is
kind of a new, uh, area of work that I'm
I've been doing recently. So I'll be
talking about each of those today. So
first of all, my own stories. These are
two of my sketchbooks. I have uh many of
these books and I've been keeping them
for about the last eight or nine years.
They accompany me wherever I go in my
life. And I fill them with all sorts of
things, records of of my lived
experience. So watercolor paintings,
drawings of uh of what I see, uh dead
flowers, dead insects, pasted ticket
stubs, rusting coins, business cards,
writings. Uh and in these books um you
can find these short little glimpses of
moments and experiences and people that
I meet and uh you know after keeping
these books for a number of years I
started to become very interested in
collecting not only my own personal
artifacts but also the artifacts of
other people. So I started collecting
found objects. This is a photograph I
found lying in a gutter in New York City
about 10 years ago. On the front, you
can see the tattered black and white
photo of a woman's face. And on the
back, it says to Judy, the girl with the
Bill Bailey voice, have fun in whatever
you do. And I really loved this idea of
the partial glimpse into somebody's
life. As opposed to knowing the whole
story, just knowing a little bit of the
story and then letting your own mind
fill in the rest. And that idea of a
partial glimpse is something that will
come back in a lot of the work I'll be
showing later today. So around this
time, I was studying computer science at
Princeton University. And I noticed that
um it was suddenly possible to collect
these sorts of personal artifacts not
just from street corners but also from
the internet and that suddenly people on
mass were leaving scores and scores of
digital footprints online that told
stories of their private lives uh blog
posts, photographs, thoughts, feelings,
opinions. All of these things were being
expressed by people online and leaving
behind trails. So I started to write
computer programs that study very very
large sets of these online footprints.
Uh, one such project is about a year and
a half old. It's called We Feel Fine.
Uh, this is a project that scans the
world's newly posted blog entries every
two or three minutes, searching for
occurrences of the phrases I feel and I
am feeling. And when it finds one of
those phrases, it grabs the full
sentence up to the period and also tries
to identify demographic information
about the author. So, their gender,
their age, their geographic location,
and what the weather conditions were
like when they wrote that sentence. It
collects about 20,000 such sentences a
day and it's been running for about a
year and a half having collected over 10
and a half million feelings. Now, uh
this is then how they're presented.
These dots here represent uh some of the
English-speaking world's feelings from
the last few hours. Uh each each dot
being a single sentence stated by a
single blogger and the color of each dot
corresponds to the type of feeling
inside. So the bright ones are happy and
the dark ones are sad. And the diameter
of each dot corresponds to the length of
the sentence inside. So, the small ones
are short and the bigger ones are
longer. I feel fine with the body I'm
in. There'll be no easy excuse for why I
still feel uncomfortable uncomfortable
being close to my boyfriend from a
22-year-old in Japan. I got this on some
trading locally, but really don't feel
like screwing with wiring and crap.
Also, some of the feelings contain
photographs in the blog posts and when
that happens, uh, these montage
compositions are automatically created,
which consist of the sentence and images
being combined. And uh any of these can
be opened up to reveal the sentence
inside.
I feel good.
I feel rough now and I probably gained
10 100,000 pounds, but it was worth it.
I love how they were able to preserve
most and everything that makes you feel
close to nature. Butterflies, man-made
forest, limestone caves, and hey, even a
huge python.
So, the next movement is called mobs.
This provides a slightly more
statistical look at things. This is
showing the world's most common feelings
overall right now, dominated by better,
then bad, then good, then guilty, and so
on. Weather uh causes the feelings to

can also stop a raindrop and and open
the feeling inside.
Uh, finally, location causes the
feelings to move to their spots on a
world map, giving you a sense of the

from We Feel Fine. These are the images
that are automatically constructed. I
feel like I'm diagonally parked in a

I've kissed numerous other boys and it

I can feel my cancer grow.
I feel pretty.
I feel skinny, but I'm not.

still be alive. I can't wait to see them

next month because I feel the need for
speed.
I feel sassy. I feel so sexy in this new
wig. As you can see, We Feel Fine um
collects very, very small scale personal
stories. Sometimes stories as short as
two or three words. So really even
challenging the notion of what can be
considered a story. And recently I've
become interested in um diving much more
deeply into a single story. And that's
led me to doing some work with the
physical world, not with the internet
and only using the internet as at the
very last moment as a presentation
medium. So these are some newer projects
that actually aren't even launched
publicly yet. The first such one is
called the whale hunt. Last May, I spent
nine days living up in Barrow, Alaska,
the northernmost settlement in the
United States, with a family of Anupia
Eskimos, documenting their annual spring
whale hunt. This is the whaling camp
here. We're about 6 miles from shore,
camping on 5 and 1/2 ft of thick frozen
pack ice. And that water that you see
there is the open lead. And through that
lead, boowhead whales migrate north each
springtime. And the Eskimo community
basically camps out on the edge of the
ice here, waits for a whale to come
close enough to attack. And when it
does, it throws a harpoon at it and then
hauls the whale up under the ice and
cuts it up. And that would provide the
community's food supply for a long time.
So I went up there and I live with these
guys out in their whaling camp here and
um photographed the entire experience
beginning with the taxi ride to Newark
airport in New York and ending with the
butchering of the second whale 7 and 1/2
days later. Photographed that entire
experience at 5minute intervals. So
every 5 minutes I took a photograph uh
when I was awake with a camera around my
neck, when I was sleeping with a tripod
and a timer. uh and then in moments of
high adrenaline like when something
exciting was happening I would up that
photographic frequency to as many as 37
photographs in 5 minutes. So what this
created was a photographic heartbeat
that sped up and slowed down more m more
or less matching the changing pace of my
own heartbeat. That was the first
concept here. The second concept was to
use this experience to think about the
fundamental components of any story.
What are the things that make up a
story? So stories have characters,
stories have concepts. Stories take
place in a certain area. They have
contexts. They have colors. What do they
look like? They have time. When did it
take place? Dates, when did it occur?
And in the case of the whale hunt, also
this idea of an excitement level. The
thing about stories though, in most of
the existing mediums that we're
accustomed to, things like novels,
radio, photographs, movies, even
lectures like this one, we're very
accustomed to this idea of the narrator
or the camera position, some kind of
omnisient external body through which
through whose eyes uh you see the story.
We're very used to this. But if you
think about real life, it's it's not
like that at all. I mean in real life
things are much more nuanced and complex
and there's all of these overlapping
stories intersecting and touching each
other. And so I thought it would be
interesting to build a framework to
surface those types of stories. So in
the case of the whale hunt, how could we
extract something like the story of
Simeon and Crawford involving the
concepts of wildlife tools and blood
taking place on the Arctic Ocean
dominated by the color red happening
around 10:00 a.m. on May 3rd with an
excitement level of high. So, how
extract this order of narrative from um
from this larger story? I built a a web
interface uh for viewing the whale hunt
that attempts to do just this. So, uh
these are all 3,214
pictures taken up there. Uh this is my
studio in Brooklyn. Uh this is the
Arctic Ocean and the butchering of the
second whale 7 days later. You can start
to see some of the story here told by
the told by color. So, this red strip uh
signifies the color of the wallpaper in
the basement apartment where I was
staying. Things go white as we move out

red down here when whales were being cut

And any of these can be clicked and then

This is the ice starting to freeze over
the snow fence they built. And so what

in the whale hunt and the two whales

Moving on. So, um, what I'm going to
tell you about next is a very new thing.
It's not even a project yet. Uh so just
yesterday I flew in here from Singapore
and before that I was spending uh two
weeks in Bhutan the small uh Himalayan
kingdom nestled between Tibet and India
and uh I was doing a project there about
uh happiness interviewing a lot of local
people. So Bhutan has this really um
wacky thing where uh they base most
their highle governmental decisions
around the concept of gross national
happiness instead of gross domestic
product. and they've been doing this
since the 70s and uh it leads to a just
a completely different value system.
It's an incredibly non-materialistic
culture where people don't have a lot
but they're incredibly happy. So I went
around and I talked to people about some
of these ideas. So I did a number of
things. I asked people a number of set
questions and took a number of set
photographs and interviewed them with
audio and also took pictures. I would
start by asking people to rate their
happiness between 1 and 10, which is
kind of inherently absurd. And then when
they answered, I would uh inflate that
number of balloons and give them that
number of balloons to hold. So you have
some really happy person holding 10
balloons and some really sad soul
holding one balloon. But you know, even
holding one balloon is like kind of
happy. Uh
uh and then I would ask them a number of
questions like what was the happiest day
in their life? What makes them happy?
And uh and then finally I would um ask
them to make a wish. And when they made
a wish, I would write their wish onto
one of the balloons and take a picture
of them holding it. So, I'm going to
show you now just a few brief snippets
of some of the interviews that I did,
some of the people I spoke with. This is
an 11-year-old student. He was playing
cops and robbers with his friends
running around town, and they all had
plastic toy guns. His wish was to become
a police officer. He was getting started
early.
Those were his hands. I took pictures of
everybody's hands because I think you
can often tell a lot from somebody about
how their hands look. I took a portrait
of everybody and asked everybody to make
a funny face. a 17-year-old student. Her
wish was to have been born a boy.
She thinks that women have a pretty
tough go at things in Bhutan, and it's a
lot easier if you're a boy.
A 28-year-old cell phone shop owner. If
you knew what Parro looked like, you'd
understand how amazing it is that
there's a cell phone shop there.
He wanted to help poor people.
a 53-year-old farmer. She was chafing
wheat and that pile of wheat behind her
had taken her about a week to make. She
wanted to keep farming until she dies.
You can really start to see the stories
told by the hands here. She was wearing
this silver ring that had the word love
engraved on it, and she found it in the
road somewhere.
a 16-year-old quarry worker. This guy
was breaking rocks with a hammer in the
hot sunlight,
but he just wanted to spend his life as
a farmer,
a 21-year-old monk. He was very happy.
He wanted to live a long life in the
monastery.
He had this amazing series of hairs
growing upole on the left side of his
face, which I'm told is very good luck.
He was kind of too shy to make a funny
face.
A 16-year-old student.
She wanted to become an independent

your chances to live an independent life
kind of end. And so she had no interest
in that.
A 24-year-old truck driver. There are

that come careening around one-lane

And he was driving one of these trucks.
But all he wanted was just to live a

a 24-year-old road sweeper. I caught her

She wanted a change in her life. She

different lot and things.
an 81-year-old itinerant farmer saw this

somewhere to live
and he had this amazing knife that he

He's all goodnatured,

He was eating this orange sugary candy

last thing we did very quickly is I took

117 interviews. 7 wishes and uh brought

is a mountain pass in Bhutan at 10,300

Bhutan. And uh up there there are
thousands of prayer flags that people
have spread out over the years. And uh
we reinflated all of the balloons, put

they're actually still flying up there
